Ever wanted to be a cyber ninja? A top-selling VR game and probably the best cyber ninja simulator ever, Sairento VR offers you that opportunity! Perform quadruple jumps, wall runs, power slides, back flips and even get to manipulate time. Empty lead into an enemy before spinning around to sink your blade into another. Kit yourself with katanas, firearms, bows, throwing glaives, shurikens, kunais and more - they are all at your disposal. Keep growing your experience and upgrading your skills. 
 
 Single player mode.
 Co-op mode.
 10 exciting maps with hordes of enemies to test your ninja skills on.

 Fight with more than 20 different types of weapons and develop your own combat style. 
 Keep upgrading your abilities and weapons as you accumulate experience from completing missions.

This game is by far the best I have ever played on my Quest. The first game I ever bought for my quest was Beat Saber, followed by Superhot. Fluffball_The_Wizard18 days ago
Hands down best mechanics I've ever seen

I've only played this game a few hours, and the more I play the more I notice it has SO much better physics and mechanics than any other game I've played. Sure, the graphics aren't the greatest but I've seen a lot worse. Definitely not distracting.

I think the main strength of this game is its insanely wide range of diverse playability. I've got my VR legs so I don't get motion sick easily, but there are tons of options for those who do, as well as being able to fine-tune every little aspect about everything in the game. I spent like an hour just playing with different settings in the dojo. I'm also ambidextrous, and FINALLY, a game that supports switching hands naturally!!! Just toss a weapon from one hand to the other! However the menus only respond to selected dominant hand rather than either one like most games, which is weird. Overall, I'm personally a power-user so I like to explore and learn to utilize every ability and feature a game has to offer, and this will keep me going for some time as there is a LOT to learn and practice. That being said, one could have lots of fun and do well only using a few moves and weapons - hence the wide range of playability.

EDIT: after getting a bit more comfortable with it, it's becoming very obvious that I need a much bigger play space to make the most out of this game. Right now I play in my small bedroom, and I must've smashed my hand on various things a dozen times in one session. Nothing wrong with the game, but beware if you also have a small space!

Coming from Space Pirate Trainer, I think Sairento has a much better execution of mechanics on reaching behind you to grab a weapon; I almost never need to try twice to get what I want whereas in SPT it's so unreliable it's quite distracting. Plus, this has 3 more places to grab for a total of 5, and it's still nearly flawless.

Hats off to the devs not only for the game but for being so responsive in the reviews. I hear they're kinda finished with this but just in case I have two suggestions so far, 1) I like to use sticky grip turned off, but doing so disables using grip to flip the direction of swords/knives. Might it be possible to have an adjustable delay so if you release and quickly press again it flips the direction without letting go? 2) My weapon of choice whenever possible is a bo staff; seems like it'd be a pretty fitting addition to a ninja game!

Overall loving this so far. Well worth the purchase.

The one I keep coming back to.

Sairento doesn't appear to be a very deep game on the surface, but spend more than an hour with it and you'll be hooked.

Appearing at once to be another wave assault game, you have a customisable set of weapons to attach to your back, side holsters and rear holster. You equip yourself from the menu before heading off into battle.

The difference between Sairento and other wave shooters is the mobility. There is smooth locomotion mixed with double or triple jumps, wall running, backflips and sliding attacks. This is going to be a problem for those sensitive to motion sickness, as they won't be able to play the game as intended.

Attacks cleave enemies into pieces, spraying limbs in the direction of your sword swing. Gunshots are meaty and headshots are satisfying.

Once you've cleared the mission, you can start equipping relics to power your armour and weapons. It's this progression system that will keep you playing, as relics have the ability to change how weapons and attacks work, leaving plenty of customisation options.

Multiplayer is functional, but animations still need work. The fella I was playing with seemed to always be bent over and looking at the floor. Not many players at all, either.

There are only 10 small-sized maps, which can get a bit repetitive. A few more would really help the variety. A few extra enemy types and weapons would also get this another star.

Still, this is one of the most fun, replayable experiences on the Quest and well worth the price compared to similar experiences. Must have - if you have your sea legs.

Rezon8Sep 14, 2019 at 11:50 PM
Parkour heaven meets Deadpool weapons!

Sairento VR: Untethered truly makes full use of the Quest's freedom of movement with no wires to get in the way of the action. I've had about 1 1/2 hours into the game playing the missions, challenges, and waves across various maps and weapon load outs. I've logged extensive hours in VR over the years, on various platforms including the Rift, Vive, Odyssey, and Pimax headsets so am not prone to motion sensitivity in VR. That said, if you are new to VR, you will need to probably take some time to acclimate yourself to the movement system, which primarily has you teleporting, wall-jumping and sliding through the various level maps.

Game premise:
You play an assassin in a futuristic neo-Tokyo underworld and must navigate through each level either based on mission, challenge, or wave shooter modes. You have 5 slots to store various weapons which you can access either on your waist holsters, reaching over your shoulders, or behind your back. There are 5 completely new levels in the Quest version vs 13 levels in the original PCVR version of the game. Another nice aspect of the game is the ability to temporarily slow down time for a few seconds so you can set up that perfect kill!

Locomotion:
There is both teleport and smooth locomotion available. However, based on the ability to do triple jumps, wall runs, and speed runs, teleport is the only way to achieve the freedom of movement that makes this game so unique and fast paced. There are snap turn options, but I found it easier to not use this at all and simply rely on physically turning. This helps to maintain better orientation to the environment.

Weapons:
Over 20 weapons in your arsenal to choose from to equip your load out. I only got through about 6 so far, so will be spending a lot more time having fun with the other weapons. I used the pistols in the beginning to keep a good distance from the enemies while I was acclimating to movement system. Reloading was a breeze, as you basically just flick the guns either down or up when you run out of bullets (you can choose either in the option settings).

As I got more comfortable however, I enjoyed using the blades and claws to inflict more close quarters damage. Surprisingly, reaching for the weapons over my shoulders, even behind my lower back, worked consistently well, in spite of the inside out tracking limitations. However, the bow and arrow handling felt slightly off and the positioning of the bow, especially drawing the arrow back closer to your head sometimes resulted in loss of tracking or glitchy hand positions. I'm hoping these can be improved in later updates.

Environment/Scene Renderings:
Obviously, due to limitations of the mobile chip, a lot of work had to be done to optimize the assets and scenes to achieve smooth performance on the Quest. Don't expect Rift quality details on this version of the game. However, if game play is paramount, and you can live with the reduced post processing FX and lowered polygons, you can spend hours in the game and definitely have a great time honing your movement and stealth skills, weapons handling and perfecting your aim. You get various bonuses based on the type of kill you make.

Level maps varied in terms of size but overall, I felt they were large enough to move around and had different floor levels and complex layouts to adequately move around without feeling walled in or cloistered. I especially liked the Subway map.

Enemies:
The enemy AI was a bit light and there were some instances where they would attack and then while I was moving around, did not re-adjust their position quickly enough to return attack, especially one of the boss enemies that looked a bit like E Honda from Street Fighter. So the challenge in defeating the enemies came from getting certain types of kills and relied less heavily on technique when it came to using close quarters weapons. The enemies were varied enough in the few levels that I played through from those firing guns, using katanas, firing energy shards, and a female assassin that would materialize, Nightcrawler style, in and out of the scene, as well as some higher level bosses at the end of the wave.

Overall Game Rating:
I'm actually quite hooked to the game and will be going back in later to do some more game play videos. Sairento VR : Untethered gets 5 out of 5 stars. The developers have really put a lot of effort into further refining gameplay elements since it was first released, improving visuals, and really listening to their fan base when it comes to implementing new content and features. Well done Mixed Realms!

Orange being the highest, many relics change how a weapon is used for example a shuriken can be thrown and can lock onto targets and smgs keep firing even when they overheat to say a few. And there are hundreds of relics to collect and experiment on with different weapons. That'll make anyone coming back, have the need of wanting more.

There's quite a few maps as well as a leveling system, a skill tree, challenges and even a relic shop. This is in my opinion without a doubt in the top 5 must have quest games without a doubt.

And there's more, the game just released multiplayer, which has furthermore increased the replayability of this game. If you like to grind in games, then this game is a no brainer. Who doesn't like to wallrun, stop time, do aerial flips in mid air and throw glaives from across the room?

As such there are a few minor improvements you could do to polish of this game and make it even more outstanding than it already is.

1. In multiplayer, the boss spawns at the same time as the rest of the enemies. Taking out the boss brings the end to the game in less than 10 seconds regardless of difficulty. If there was a way to bring in the boss 'only' after all the enemies were defeated, or to be able to finish of the level by killing the rest of the enemies would solve this issue, and would make multiplayer more enjoyable, longer and ultimately more fun.

2. Experience points. In multiplayer only, you get so much points after bringing down the boss. You gain 6 or 7 levels each time which doesn't happen in single player. This makes me think it's a bug or an exploit that shouldn't happen. Together with point number 1, it makes multiplayer far too easy and not challenging enough.

3. There isn't any other game types other than taking down the boss within multiplayer. I'd like to see other game modes for example; survival and time attack from single player or perhaps a new game mode entirely.

4. Challenges are for single player at the moment, it would be great if you could add some multiplayer challenges too.

5. More weapon types so that you can feel more of a true baddy.

I very much believe these improvements can be possible, the first couple I want to see first though. I know multiplayer is just out and you're working hard already. You can have any combination, dual wield on both shoulders and hips and an extra weapon slot on your lower back all at the same time. This game has it all.

Should of been a Quest launch title.

Well this is a suprise. I didn't expect to like this so much, I've never been a huge fan of the cyber ninja look, but the real star is the gameplay.

6 - 8 Hour of play.
There is nothing like sliding along the ground and chopping a dudes legs off or using a bow like it's Breath of the Wild and slowing down time for that perfect shot. It did take me about an hour to get used to the movement but once I did, it's incredible.

To keep this short and sweet. Is it worth it? Oh yes. I think I would have bought this if it were in the 15-20 range because the gameplay is so tight, so it's defiantly worth 10.99. This is a must have for fans of intense action VR games.

Finally, I will update this review over time, this above is 6-8 hours of experience. Below is the following hours.

8 - 18 Hours of play.
First things first, each weapon is incredible! All of them have a completely different levels of mastery and attachable items (maybe except the three swords the game offers which are nearly all the same).
The game starts you off duel wielding swords & pistols with a backup SMG, but if thats not your style and you want a more ninja like experience you can switch out to a sword wielding, arrow shooting, shuriken throwing executioner. You can even just drop the whole stealth act and run around with shotguns, assault rifles and other speical weapons.
Another addition and important game mechanic is weapon attachments/buffs/Relics, these can change a weapon slightly or drastically, increasing its aim assist, damage and ammo pool, thats the normal ones. Then you get things like projectiles bounce of the surfaces, throw 2 more shuriken's, stealthy attacking increases damage by 200%. This leads to having very creative builds and there is so much more.
The main reason I'm talking more about the weapons is because thats the big reason you want to play this game and the main reasons you will keep playing.

Missions are just that, missions. There isn't a campaign so the draw to play the game is to get better gear, to do harder missions and get further in the challenging endless mode. There is a few different type of missions and more than a few maps, but the objective is always, kill the dudes and survive.

I still keep coming back to this game but I can now see where the end point may be. Once I have got all the upgrades or when I feel like the game gets to easy or I get far enough into endless mode that I can be proud of.

I will probably update this one more time when I feel like I can put this game down for a bit and wait for extra content or a DLC to drop. But overall this is the best action game on the Quest.
Thanks for reading.

A stunning ballet of violence

I was underwhelmed with this at first, having played the SteamVR version. But I fiddled with the (considerable) options to enable full locomotion and the more brilliant silly stuff like gliding, slo-mo backflips and changing katana grip angle to 'stab'.

And then it blew my mind. It encourages creative and varied play, and the more ridiculous you try to be, the more the game rises to meet you. Zipping through the air headshotting with your Deckard-style pistols and then grabbing your katanas as you land to eviscerate the fool behind you... It's incredible. It seems to have the single goal of making you feel like an unstoppable future ninja and gives you all the tools to make that happen.

It's scrappier than the likes of Robo Recall, but the team behind this obviously has a lot of passion and talent and the feel is perfect. It's a complete steal at this price and represents a real jewel in the Quest's crown. The more you play it, the more it demands to be played.

I know that trade-offs had to be made from the Steam version, and I don't really care - but what I do miss is the missions where you move between areas, like the compartments of a train. Arenas are all very well, but I'm sure that a bit of jiggery pokery would allow discrete rooms for the player to move between once all of the enemies in one had been killed.

Also, I really love the way that stealth works in this game and I wish there was more of it. There's nothing like dropping from the rafters and stabbing someone in the back before being spotted, or picking off the scouts one by one from the towers.

One last thing - the kurisigama is bloody astonishing. Thank you Mixed Realms for a stunning game - I can't wait to see where you take it and I'm glad to be on board.

4.5 Stars

Sairento is really fun to play. The movement system is the best part about the game by far and I hope others implement this waypoint/teleport hybrid system in other games.

Locomotion can be very disorienting and I have been inconsistently getting sick. Sometimes Im sick in 15 mins and sometimes I dont get sick for over an hour of playing. So, take the game in small increments and frequent breaks until your brain gets used to it.

The downside is that the graphics really have taken a hit. Although the weapon textures are amazing, the textures for enemies are pretty bad. I like the way a couple enemies look, the geisha and blue samurai look pretty good, but others look almost like N64 models. A couple levels are graphically more impressive than the others as well so this leads me to believe that it could be better overall with some optimization.

Content is very deep. The relic bonuses are useful for stats and some added skills feel like you are progressing, but you start with every weapon there will be in the game. I would have preferred to have limited basic weapons while unlocking some more as the game progressed as part of the loot system. For example, the starting swords this way have no benefit over the others as some do more damage straight away.

Overall the game is very fun and though the Quest chip is rather limiting for graphics, I do believe that models and textures could be improved either by restylizing some enemies or rounding polygons out a bit more.

For the price this game is really incredible. If they add more content like they plan to, hopefully with weapons(or skins), maps, and enemies, the game will be infinitely replay-able. At the moment, however, you still at least get your moneys worth and can build up your VR legs while having a lot of fun.
